text: All right, good afternoon everybody. I

far. My name is Kevin and together with
Ty and Vignesh from CD Project, we will
take you behind the scenes on the topic
of large scale animated foliage,
specifically in the context of the
Witcher 4 Unreal Gym 5 tech demo. This
is the demo we showcased at um Unreal
Fest Orlando just a few months ago.
So the story arc of today's session is
us telling you about the difficulties of
rendering foliage to early experiments
leading into solutions and finally talk
about how this collaboration and demo
culminates in you know engine features
for you guys to try out in 5.7.
So before we kick things off here's a
brief snippet from the demo um just to
set the tone. It is running on a base
PS5 at 60 fps with all the bells and
whistles that UI5 has to offer.
So, bit of a spoiler for those who
haven't seen it. This is kind of the
middle section of the demo where we go
on rails and we just kind of fly
through, look at all the awesome foliage
and vegetation tech that we built. And
uh in case you haven't seen it, you
know, it's online. You can see it in its
full glory. And as we move up here,
we're going to catch up with our
protagonist and continue the demo, but
we're going to skip that part for now.
So, I'm going to hand it over to Ty to

to tell you more about 5.7 stuff. All
right, take it away, Ty.
>> All right. Um, so from the very start,
we set ourselves two goals. First of
all, we wanted the player to feel like
they're in a huge forest, but we also
wanted the forest to feel alive. So,
basically, it responds naturally to
forces from the environment, especially
wind. Uh, and we wanted uh this to work
not just on a small scale, but really uh
push it as far as we can.
But first we had to start with uh
yeah basically from nothing uh cuz there
was no nanite foliage at that time. So
why is foliage hard? Um well foliage has
always been a challenge in video games.
Um the state-of-the-art solution hasn't
changed much in a very long time. Um
there were some improvements made for
sure, but fundamentally we're making
trees and foliage the same way. We're
using cards. for using alpha testing.
Um, and many of the advantages that
Nanite gave, they didn't apply to
foliage.
So, first we tried cards. Uh, we started
with yeah the kind of known solution on
the screen. You can see uh an tree, the
same tree made with cards and made with
geometry. It's kind of the reference
mesh. So, the uh cards approach um I
would not recommend it in any case. It's
still around three to four times slower
than uh trying to uh mesh it out and let
Nanite handle the geometry. Um but if
you do use cards, we found that it's
well try to make the geometry um match
the cards as closely as possible. So
don't have big planes. Try to cut it out
if you can. But generally, yeah, we
recommend staying away from uh alpha
testing.
So why is alpha testing slow? Well,
especially in the software reser, the
main reason is the berry centrics. So,
nanite uh it handles all the geometry in
one fixed function pipeline. But with
alpha testing, this is no longer
possible. Um the reason it's slow is
that in the in the inner loop of the
softwareizer, we need to calculate the
barentrics to get the UVs and then
sample the alpha mask. Um you can see
this nanite reserization common file for
the logic. Uh but because it's in the
inner loop of the software rusterizer,
well there's a heavy performance penalty
to pay. Um that that is not easy to get
around.
So we tried the other approach. We tried
geometry. Um this uh had some
advantages. We didn't use alpha. Uh it
was faster to render because it didn't
have this problem with the barentrics.
It also looked better uh because we
didn't have to kind of fake the normals
which yeah vegetations artists have
gotten very good at over the years. Um
but this kind of gave us good server
scattering and all that out of the box.
But there was another problem. Um mainly
the disk size and the RAM. Uh so nanite
geometry um it rendered quite fast but
we were using yeah like up to 63
megabytes of VRAM for a single tree
versus 6 megabytes of cards. So a 10x
increase in memory usage and even more
on disk a 30x increase. So we would be
shipping a huge huge game if we made all
our foliage this way.
Next, there is also just the inherent
problem of foliage, which is um that
it's hard to build good LODs for it. Uh
Nanite has the preserve area flag, which
is well an absolute must for foliage,
otherwise it will just disappear, but it
doesn't do even with the flag, it
doesn't do a great job of keeping the
shape at the distance. As you can see
here, on the left, you see a rock and on
the right you see a tree. So clearly the
um the quality of the rock LOD is much
higher where the uh tree basically
becomes becomes a triangle soup. And
that's just an inherently hard problem
to try to model uh a tree with a very
low triangle count.
Plus all the holes that are um yeah that
you can see in the geometry they also
cause excessive overdraw. So it's not
just um worse lots, they're also more
expensive.
And then we have animation. So we
started out again with kind of industry
best practice which was Vert.ex shader
based wind. Uh there was you know plenty
of out of the box solutions available.
We started with pivot pivot painter 2
which was a vert.x shader based wind. uh
where the artist would yeah store
basically in the textures the pivots in
the hierarchy of the tree um that we
then evaluate at runtime in the vertex
shader. Um actually it reminded us a lot
of skeletal animation how this approach
was doing it but it was all happening in
the vertex shader.
And as you may remember from well uh
earlier slides uh if we go with geometry
we have a lot of vertices. Um even with
cards we're around yeah 100k but with
geometry we're over a million vertices
that need to be transformed at runtime.
So it was quite clear that uh the work
that we need to do for each vertex needs
to be absolutely minimal.
And there's another problem uh which is
that using uh um vertx shader logic to
move things around or world position
offset um the way to handle uh the
cluster bounds in the night is that you
need to inflate them. So in this case we
can imagine the tree on the right being
our our kind of reference tree and uh uh
the the rotated tree is the one that's
animated. that little green box that you
see that those are the cluster bounds of
that particular cluster up top which is
used for calling within nanite um and it
is very very important for performance.
Now if we want to move those vertices to
that point we have to inflate those
cluster bounds so that they fit the
original uh position. So that means they
need to be absolutely huge. And while
you may say well foliage is not good at
occlusion culling anyway also remember
that these cluster bounds are used for
invalidating vsm pages. Uh so clearly um
vertex shader animation was not the way
to go.
So we needed some new solutions. Um we
saw potential in nanite especially for
geometry but it was also clear that we
had to uh develop on it to make it work.
So one of the first things we did was
skin foliage. Um this was quite quickly
proving to be a success. Um we switched
from doing everything in the vertex
shader to a two pass system. Uh where uh
we first calculated all the bones, their
transformations, did the animations on a
compute shader and then in the vertex
shader just moved the vertices around.
Um this was quite cheaply done. We also
went with uh rigid skinning. Uh this was
a good enough trade-off for us where we
only had one bone influence one vertex.
Uh this could also result in potential
benefits later such as with ray tracing.
And we ended up using uh skin foliage in
the in the demo.
We also tried to make alpha testing
work. We didn't go full in on geometry
right away. Um the first thing that we
tried was Nanite but with custom LODs.
So basically we were using Nanite as it
works out of the box but we um had
manual LODs at certain distances. This
did bring uh good perf improvement
around 20 to 30%. Uh but it also came
with downsides like brought back popping
and all the other issues associated with
cards. Um so this this was not enough
for us uh to kind of achieve that vision
that we had.
Then with the help of epic we also tried
to optimize the software restorer as
much as we could to make the alpha
testing uh as fast as we can. Um and
significant improvements were made but
we started hitting diminishing returns.
So um at that point it was kind of clear
that alpha testing was just a no-go.
One other thing that we considered but
didn't pursue was inspired by opacity
micro maps. If you're familiar with it
is a technique used in ray tracing to

cards and alpha testing. This idea could
be transferred to the nanite software
rasterizer to basically get rid of that
expensive barentric calculation that I
was talking about earlier and to use a
more efficient way of well basically
checking if this pixel is opaque or not.
But in the end we didn't pursue this
direction because the geometry was
showing more potential.
So there's no alpha foliage in a demo
anywhere. Not even the small foliage.
Everything is uh using the uh same

just hitting the instance limit in the

And we also had to pay with for the cost
that comes with an instance. Unreal

actually stores quite a lot of data. And
really, we didn't need this data. What
we needed was very lightweight
instances.
